As a education major, I feel that intergrating all arts ( certainly music) into the classroom is very important to the students' education. Using the fine arts in the classroom increases the students' motovation to learn.

It's definitely important. A lot of kids can memorize song lyrics in a day but can't spell at all. So, give them a tune and they can spell to the tune and learn it. It can be a memorization tool. Another thing, it teaches you to use your right brain for the creative aspect and left brain with the beat. It strengthens your whole brain. One time all my teachers took a test to see which half of their brain was stronger. The math/science teachers got left and English teachers got right. The music teacher was the only one to get "whole brain'".

Music, art as in drawing, painting, sculture, etc., theater, dance, the whole damn spectrum of art should be integrated into education. To do otherwise is to cheat all students.
 
 Not to mention mathematics, which is an artform, after all, and all the basics, reading, writing, geography, history, social studies, governmental studies, the whole spectrum of human experience--including sex education.
 
 Hades! We're human! We must study humanity! OK, the other species, too, geology, meteorology, physics, chemistry, etc., etc.
 
 But, how to accomplish all this? Back to the drawing board. Guess we don't have any time left to study religion and stuff of that ilk, hehe.

Music is definitely an important aspect of education. Everyone should take at least very preliminary courses, if not in music, at least in the arts (theater, drama, music, art, poetry, etc.) just so they can learn to tolerate/appreciate it. Then more advanced courses should be offered to those interested, but not required.
Music is defintely important. Things like music, art, etc etc give kids their creativity, math and english do not. They are only there to help communicate.

 Definitely YES!
Excuse me, but I think that your just specifying one kind of music. I for one am in Band and Choir, and I find that these classes are good for my mental developement.emoticon_xgood

Music is more than just an important part of education, it's an important part of being human. People have been making music together since prehistory, it's a socially bonding act that's part of our social nature. Making music makes people feel good.
 
 Besides that, learning an instrument and playing with others teaches kids useful social skills, and teaches them that commitment has rewards, that it is good to challenge yourself. 
 
 It also focuses the mind on a complex activity which is good for your concentration, analytical thinking, and the ability to think on your feet, especially, for example, if you're improvising a solo. Encouraging kids to make music gives them confidence to be spontaneous and creative, as well as diligent and hard-working.
 
 One problem is often the way it's taught, and it's often quite expensive to teach kids music in an enjoyable and productive way. If a school has plenty of money they can afford pianos, keyboards and other instruments that the pupils can use, because to really experience music you have to have a chance at doing it yourself. If a school can't afford many (or any) instruments, then its music department is pretty much pointless; not many young teenagers are keen to learn about the life of Mozart, or learn how to write a Bach chorale. There's a world of difference between academic music and performance, and while the former is important it cannot be appreciated without the latter.
 
 It's best if kids are involved at the local level, with many schools and the local authorities co-ordinating with parents to provide a dedicated youth music centre with a wealth of instruments and full-time tutors. I was fortunate enough to live in an area of south London with just such a set-up when I was younger. While the tutors charged for individual lessons, there were several dozen bands, choirs and orchestras that you could join for a small annual membership fee, all of whom put on regular concerts. The trust also recieved money from local government and local businesses. When I left school there were about 5,000 local kids involved in one ensemble or another.
 
 In addition, there were a few ensembles which required a high level of commitment and were pushed harder and put on more ambitious performances than the others, allowing kids to take it more seriously for greater rewards if they commited to putting the effort in. 
 
 While it takes a lot of time, effort and co-ordination to set up, it's an incredibly valuable resource for the community because it's good for the kids and it's something for everyone involved in to enjoy and be proud of.

Of course music is beneficial to education, but lots of kids will take this simply as an invitation to listen to all of that inappropriate swear-word-filled modern junk, right? Is THAT kind of music good for you too?

Of course music is beneficial to education, but lots of kids will take this simply as an invitation to listen to all of that inappropriate swear-word-filled modern junk, right? Is THAT kind of music good for you too?

 
 Yes.
 
 Music has always been a 'turn your nose up at it' kind of thing whenever something new and non-mainstream comes into play. People thought Bach lost his marbles, and he was forgotten until Mendelssohn came along and dug his stuff out. Stravinksy? Whew, did he make a stink at the beginning of the 20th century. And have you even read one of the libretti from, oh, any late nineteenth century German opera? People went into conniptions!
 
 Swear words are just expression.
 
 All that being said, I hate swear word filled modern junk and think most pop artists these days have zero musical talent and it all sounds the same. Breaking the mold, that is the way to be remembered.

 I agree with what you say about modern pop music (or most of it). But are you making a case for 'exposing' students to classical music in the hope that some of them will develop a taste for it?

This is why students need to be encouraged to make music rather than just listen to it or study it.
 Give them oboes, trumpets, pianos, guitars, drums, give them anything and let them be creative and they may come to enjoy all forms of music because they can identify with it.
 As for pop music and its lack of talented individuals, there are some artists out there who are creative and talented who are popular enough to enter the public consciousness (for example, off the top of my head, Muse, Orbital, Red Hot Chili Peppers). That the vast majority of it "sounds the same" is not a situation that is unique to our time.
 Music has always been primarily about dancing, which is primarily about sex. Therefore it is not surprising that the most popular music is music which is easy and fun to dance to, which requires that it is not very complex and is repetetive. Even before electronic music, before rock n roll, before the twentieth century, the vast majority of 'classical' music was dance music, which has not entered into posterity because it was simple, generic and transient.
 In a hundred years' time, while Hendrix, The Beatles, Pink Floyd, the Pixies, Muse, Eminem and others will be remembered as the 'greats' of 20th century music, the vast majority of what we see in the charts every week will have been forgotten, but this will not lessen the continuous output of generic dance music because people love to dance.

Of course music is beneficial to education, but lots of kids will take this simply as an invitation to listen to all of that inappropriate swear-word-filled modern junk, right? Is THAT kind of music good for you too?

(To those that do know, he plays about 20 instruments and does most of his recording alone. His first album was written, performed and produced by him - every vocal, every instrument - it dabbles with blues, funk, country and rock - and the man was 18 years old.)

 The reason I do find rap appealing is that it's rythmic based - not melody based. They use voice, instruments and all manner of sound as a rythem instrument.

The reason I do find rap appealing is that it's rythmic based - not melody based. They use voice, instruments and all manner of sound as a rythem instrument.

 
 The elements of a conventional musical composition would include melody, harmony, rhythm, and dynamics. 
 
 So what you say here implies that rap cannot be described as music. And I would agree.
 
 Rap is a form of rhythmic shouting - possibly a cousin to the cheerleader's chorus of encouragement at a football match.
 
 I believe what you call the 'lyrics' of rap are of first importance, and I suppose shouting them with rhythmic urgency appeals to atavistic passions.
 
 But it is not music.

 To hell with convention. 
 
 Rap is not the first music to rely on complex rythems with minimal to no use of melody. With your logic every drum soloist would not be a musician. Do you feel this way when guitar, flute, clarinet, or anything instrument that is traditionally melodic solos as well? And quite frankly, most contemporary music under utilizes their rythem section - most of the basslines I hear in country, pop, and most contemporary rock would bore me to tears to play.
 
 Much rap and hip hop utilizes melodies in the rythem, but not in a traditional way - it all becomes a heartbeat, a throb, a pulse, it matches emotion in different, more primal way. To compare it to cheerleading is highly insulting to literally thousands of MUSICIANS who bust their asses in this genre.
 
 I have minimal patience for trying to convert opinion to definition.

To compare it to cheerleading is highly insulting to literally thousands of MUSICIANS who bust their asses in this genre.
 
 I have minimal patience for trying to convert opinion to definition.

 Your reaction to 'convention' is a bit wild. 
 
 A convention can be a set of rules - like say the rules that we follow when speaking or writing. Unless you followed those rules, I couldn't understand what you have to say: we couldn't communicate with one another.
 
 Music is a language that speaks directly to the emotions - to the heart, if you like. But the elements of music - melody, harmony, rhythm, dynamics - aren't just matters of opinion. They're the structural essentials.
 
 My 'logic' doesn't deny musicianship to the drummer - who (or might be part of a section) provides the rhythmic pulse in a piece of music. But rhythm is only one element in a performance - not the whole 'product'. The drummer make take a solo, but that's not understood to be more than an exciting contribution to the total effect. 
 
 Generally speaking, if you can hold a tune, you can hum it, tap out its rhythm, add notes to it and produce a harmony, or play variations on it. With the exception perhaps of the rhythmic pulse, none of these musical possibilities exist in rap. And that's why I said it isn't music.
 
 By the way, we're never going to agree on this one - but there's no need to yell at each other, or pretend to be insulted, or make out that I'm trying to convert opinion to definition. I know the difference.

 OK, so you don't agree with me. Why does that make what I have to say 'XXXX'? Is your opinion the last word on this subject?
 
 You say I'm ill-informed yet I notice that you carefully avoided commenting on what I said about holding a tune. If you want to pretend that rap is music and bellow fatuous imprecations against anyone who can give reasons for contradicting you, there's no point in continuing this 'discussion'. I'm not interested in trading adolescent insults.

Some examples of musical genres that do not necessarily include the elements you have classified as "structural essentials":
 
 Minimalism. 20/21st Century Modern. Techno. Pre-Baroque. Baroque. Gregorian Chant. Percussion solo. African drumming. Eastern/Asian.
 
 I hope you try out something new and discover something you enjoy. :)

 
 I would agree that some Baroque and pre-Baroque music is 'formalised' and the melody element is in abeyance. I don't know much about Gregorian Chant - except that it employs a modal idiom in plainchant melodies. I haven't listened to much of it, but I like what I've heard. It's very beautiful, but an acquired taste. 
 
 I would not describe the other genres you mention as music in the complete sense I have been reckless enough to define. Except for Eastern/Asian - to which I am partial - though I'm ignorant about the musical structure of any its varieties.
 
 My musical tastes are quite eclectic as anyone who glanced at my collection of CDs could confirm. I'm an amateur musician, not a professional critic.
 
 By the way, the reasonable tone of your comments is appreciated.
 
 Too often, anyone who speaks up in defence of 'traditional' musical concepts or expression, is shrieked at and howled down by the 'radical' spirits of the age.

The elements of a conventional musical composition would include melody, harmony, rhythm, and dynamics.

 
 Music:
 
 1. The art of arranging sounds in time so as to produce a continuous, unified, and evocative composition, as through melody, harmony, rhythm, and timbre.
 
 2. Vocal or instrumental sounds possessing a degree of melody, harmony, or rhythm.
 
 3.
 1. A musical composition.
 2. The written or printed score for such a composition.
 3. Such scores considered as a group: We keep our music in a stack near the piano.
 
 4. A musical accompaniment.
 
 5. A particular category or kind of music.
 
 6. An aesthetically pleasing or harmonious sound or combination of sounds: the music of the wind in the pines.
 
 Apparently, melody is not required to define something as music.

OK, so you don't agree with me. Why does that make what I have to say 'XXXX'? Is your opinion the last word on this subject?
 
 You say I'm ill-informed yet I notice that you carefully avoided commenting on what I said about holding a tune. If you want to pretend that rap is music and bellow fatuous imprecations against anyone who can give reasons for contradicting you, there's no point in continuing this 'discussion'. I'm not interested in trading adolescent insults.

 
 It's music. It is accepted as such by just about everybody but you. It is accepted as such by PROFESSIONAL musicians, while, as you claim, you are not one. Whether or not it is music is about as debatable as whether or the not the thing under my tush right now is a chair.
 
 Whether or not it is music you like, or it is music you think is good are debatable points. Whether or it is music at all is not - and the attempts to claim otehrwise reek of the type of arrogance that has ruined the arts for regular people throughout eons. It's attitudes like this that have pedastaled some artists so much that average every day folk deem it untouchable - and it insults every change, experiment, or attempt to create something new. It is an arrogrant, ugly, mean-sprirted thing to do. Millions of people create, enjoy and find that rap speaks to them and you insult them all. I find joy in classical, rock, celtic, and RAP - so you insult me with your arrogance as well. I am not being adolescent - I am being offended and letting you know it.

I don't know much about Gregorian Chant - except that it employs a modal idiom in plainchant melodies. I haven't listened to much of it, but I like what I've heard. It's very beautiful, but an acquired taste. 
 
 I would not describe the other genres you mention as music in the complete sense I have been reckless enough to define. Except for Eastern/Asian - to which I am partial - though I'm ignorant about the musical structure of any its varieties.
 
 My musical tastes are quite eclectic as anyone who glanced at my collection of CDs could confirm. I'm an amateur musician, not a professional critic.
 
 By the way, the reasonable tone of your comments is appreciated.
 
 Too often, anyone who speaks up in defence of 'traditional' musical concepts or expression, is shrieked at and howled down by the 'radical' spirits of the age.

 
 I was considering not just melody, but the others you mentioned such as harmony and dynamics. Harmony just didn't exist for a long time and dynamics weren't used either. We seem to have come full circle into the modern/minimalist movement. Certainly an aquired taste, and many of it seems destined to rot on shelves in music libraries until some Mendelssohn of the time comes around and brings to it new popularity in the public eye. (The whole Bach/Mendelssohn thing. Thank Mendelssohn next time you hear "Air on the G String" at a wedding.)

While I retain a little bit of that musical snobbism, I discovered that I enjoy all genres. Even though I get made fun of when I put in the latest "Moby" album. Or Enya. Boy, do I hear it for that! :)

It's music. It is accepted as such by just about everybody but you. It is accepted as such by PROFESSIONAL musicians, while, as you claim, you are not one. Whether or not it is music is about as debatable as whether or the not the thing under my tush right now is a chair.
 
 Whether or not it is music you like, or it is music you think is good are debatable points. Whether or it is music at all is not - and the attempts to claim otehrwise reek of the type of arrogance that has ruined the arts for regular people throughout eons. Yes, I thought you'd accuse me of being a musical snob because I don't regard rap as music. I'm also (you tell me) BORING, and ill-informed. I also talk 'XXXX', apparently.

 You are a musical snob. And it's a bit hard to discuss musical tastes with somebody who won't condescend to consider music he dislikes as music at all.

On this point (that RAP is XXXX) I totally agree with Alan Ryan. I will not deny the popularity of it as it seems to have quite a following that is apparently willing to forego all true music and listen to nothing but XXXX.
 
 Not that there aren't some profound words in XXXX, but an astonishment with lyrics, rhyming or not, can be described as an appreciation for poetry. I like poetry. I like music...ALL KINDS of music.
 
 The talent required to compose a good symphonic piece is infinite compared to the talent required to be a shock-jock, jumping around in baggy clothes, chanting and giving the finger to the audience. All RAP seems to convey is disrespect for normalcy.
 
 I'm betting the Old Masters are rolling over at the news that a XXXX 'song' beat out real music at the Oscars. But then, maybe they considered the source, too. Hollywood is replete with numbnuts who think wierdness is the going thing.

Since the "crisis of tonality" at the beginning of the 20th century, the definition of what music is has become ever broader (at least as defined by musicians and composers) to the point where today music is pretty much "any combination of sound" in the same way that visual arts encompass everything from the Sistine Chapel ceiling to Damien Hirst's preserved, bisected animals.
 
 I don't fully agree with this, and believe the definition must be qualified by including the phrase "that has an emotive effect on the listener". I see this as the primary purpose of art; it is an emotional expression which produces emotional responses in others. This is why art is so subjective, there can exist an artwork which the vast majority of people find pointless and uninteresting, but someone may find something in it which affects them personally.
 
 Of course sometimes it is hard to distinguish between someone having a genuine emotional response and someone just waffling on about a pice of XXXX which they have decided to consider 'art' because it makes them look intellectual. You can often see these people coming, however, by virtue of their propensity to wear scarves in all weathers, berets and beards which they can stroke as they practice their intellectual one-upmanship.
 
 Bringing this back to music, it was only a short period in history (roughly 17th to 19th centuries) when for something to be considered 'music' it must contain all the compositional elements; melody, harmony, rhythm and form. Referring to the example of rap, not only does it have its roots not in Western musical ideologies, it is very much in keeping with the evolution of music during the twentieth century as it focuses on rhythm; the major orchestral composers of the early C20th focused on rhythm as a means to combat the impossibility of being original while remaining within the tonal system evolved by Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Wagner among others. 
 
 The 'classical' music of these composers' times was the ultimate expression of complex interactions of sets of chords; there was only a finite amount of combinations and orderings. It can be argued that Bach himself had already explored the entire tonal system in his works, and everything written by those who came after him was just an elaboration, with more and more complex decorations as time went on.
 
 This was an entirely Western tradition with its own rules and its own taboos. As time went by the rules were bent more and more out of shape, and the taboos became more and more ignored. Add to this the self-conscious desire of Stravinsky, Schoenberg et al to create new basic premises for compositional strategies, and also add the arrival of other cultural forms into the template of Western music during the C20th, and the advent of electronic music, and you have the multi-faceted musical scene we know today, which is a combination of so many styles and influences reaching back so far in time, incorporating conflicting ideologies and different cultures, that trying to impose classifications of "music/not music" seems pointless.

The talent required to compose a good symphonic piece is infinite compared to the talent required to be a shock-jock, jumping around in baggy clothes, chanting and giving the finger to the audience.

 
 True, but "good symphonic pieces", and the talented artists who wrote them, were few and far between compared to the vast majority of 'classical' music which consisted mostly of two kinds of piece:
 
 1) Simple dances written for all kinds of social occasion, which could be rattled off in a couple of hours by the most basically trained composer, and which were usually full of plagiarism, even self-plagiarism.
 
 2) Impressive symphonic works which nevertheless were simply imitations of the current crop of 'masters'.
 
 The same situation exists today; the vast majority of 'artists' are either just churning out XXXX to make money, or copying other popular trends, to make money. However there will always be diamonds in the rough: You cannot deny that Eminem is a talented lyricist, or that groups like Roots and Jurassic 5 are genuinely creative, and trying to push boundaries. 
 
 Most rap IS XXXX, but so is most music, from the brainless dance music we see in the charts, to unimaginative generic rock, to the sensationalist "gangsta" rap which promotes violence and degrades women. All this music has one thing in common; it appeals to the lowest common denominator and is all about making money.
 
 Those who buck trends and try to be original are often not noticed while they are being most prolific; it is only later when it becomes obvious that they have surreptitiously influenced the next generation of music that they are hailed as the creative artists they were. 
 
 As for the amount of sheer intellectual/creative talent involved, this is hard to define. 'Classical' music is unarguably more complex, more intricate, more cerebral than rap, but it is also the most complex, intricate and cerebral music that the human race has ever come up with. There is nothing to compare to pieces like Beethoven's 9th, or Wagner's Ring cycle, because no contemporary music has such complex foundations. But "talent" in terms of learned ability to create compex structures is not the same as "talent" in terms of pure creativity, which exists in all true artists, who are always in the minority.

The talent required to compose a good symphonic piece is infinite compared to the talent required to be a shock-jock, jumping around in baggy clothes, chanting and giving the finger to the audience. All RAP seems to convey is disrespect for normalcy.

 
 Spoken just like someone who has never listened to it. 
 
 What the hell is normalcy? Rap style is certainly more normal where I live, I bet you anything, than you and your truck would be. You know, when in Rome....
 
 You know, its interesting, I am not even a particularly big rap fan, but I can recognize a thing for what it is - and it is a very powerful musical medium.
 
 Me, for example, couldn't find much in the music world more dull and self-absorbed than jazz - but I don't run around feeling the need to negate the ability or efforts of jazz musicians.
 
 Jim, Alan - you sound like my old man.... yawn yawn yawn

The talent required to compose a good symphonic piece is infinite compared to the talent required to be a shock-jock, jumping around in baggy clothes, chanting and giving the finger to the audience. All RAP seems to convey is disrespect for normalcy.
 

 
 Yes, but most musicians don't compose good symphonic pieces. If we level the playing field, comparing it to rock, country, or pop, I would say the talent is about the same. Most music today consists of pretty simple chords, a melody, and lyrics. Rap consists of a good beat, a "melody" (don't know if you can quite call it a melody, but sort of the tone of voice and the rhythm of the words along with sometimes a real melody in the background), and mostly rhyming lyrics. I'd say the talent is about even, neither is easy, which is why if you're really good at it, you can make quite a bit of money. And if you can sing/rap really well too? Prepare to rake in the dough.

I'm one who prefers static to Rap, but the discussion so far has not mentioned one of the benefits it provides. Rap provides a means for many with little or no musical talent to make a good living. I am beginning to believe that listening to Rap must lead to poor hearing, since many insist on playing it very loud. I don't care what others choose to listen to, but I do wish they could keep it to themselves.

While I don't expect you to take the time out of your day to listen to radio stations and search the web for music you don't appreciate, a lot of the music covered by the rap umbrella is very different from that which you describe.

 An earnest critic was droning on about contemporary music and asked Beecham if he'd ever played any Stockhausen. He replied, "No, but I believe I once trod in some".

 I try not to put down any type of music, unless doing so in jest. For example, I'm a believer that when you play twangy country music backwards, your wife reappears and your dog comes back. ;)
 But, I digress. Rap music has its roots in black protest music of the late 60's -early 70's by artists such as Gil Scott Heron and the Last Poets. The lyrics were typically raw but their poetry told stories about life to a bongo drum backbeat. My first encounter with this genre was during my teens. In fact, I still have the first Last Poets album somewhere. I had to hide it because it came with the lyrics printed on it. My parents would have freaked out if they had ever read (or heard) the lyrics.emoticon_wow Needless-to-say, it was listened to discretely. 
 http://www.gilscottheron.com/lyrevol.html
 http://www.furious.com/perfect/lastpoets.html
 As rap grew from black protest music, technology was introduced in the form of scratching records. This replaced the drum beat and the exaggerated emphasis of certain words provided a counter beat. I'm not a big fan of rap music, but it's not because I turn my nose up over its musicality. I just think that too much of it is derrogarory towards women.

emoticon_love Oh Boy! Music is so important for a young mind! I am booster president for our high school band. I have seen students come in to a band and not know one person, because of music, by the end of the year they are friends with 50! Students learn to get along to make it work. Music helps in so many ways, it helps to calm, it sooths, it helps to celebrate, it gives cheer and joy. emoticon_xlove Students learn to listen, learn to hear, learn to give and learn to care. I have seen kids with every thing pierced on the face, they come in to the band room & sit next to the kid with the polo shirt and khakis, they have one thing in common-MUSIC! They play together, as one! It is great! It isn't about who wears what or who has more money, it is about the music! It's about compassion and the love of the music! It is proven, children who are exposed to music, grow to be intelligant and caring adults. Maybe some adults need to stop and listen to more music!emoticon_xgood

post_info.post_title: Music is the most important lesson

Music is a kind of art class and is therefore one of the most important parts of a school. Art classes are the most important and foundational classes, and should be at the center of all schools - with all other lessions relateing to them.

Being a musician myself, I strongly feel that Music is an essential part to a students schedule. To me, there is no greater joy than having a solo in the jazz band, and showing others that you are making something your own. That you have shaped a beautiful work of the human mind, and have somehow connected to everyone else in that room. Whenever I play if I have connectedto just one person, if I have seen that I have made someone feel, someone just embrace the very basic wonderings of the imagination, I know I have done my job. Without Music, life is dull, creativity dead, and the ideals of many bright people crushed by the turmoil and worries of life. One must pause and just breathe. Just put on your favorite record, whether it be Michale Brecker (God help him as he battles cancer) or Bach, just try to imerse yourself in each and every note played. That everyone is the apex of human understanding, that is the point where one realizes there is soemthing more to life than just 9-5, or that math assignment. There is feeling in the world,a nd an adventure awaits everyone who wishs to seek their own way to understanding and tranquility.

Music is a kind of art class and is therefore one of the most important parts of a school. Art classes are the most important and foundational classes, and should be at the center of all schools - with all other lessions relateing to them.

 
 And we wonder why the US performs near the bottom in math and science. :xbanghead

And we wonder why the US performs near the bottom in math and science. :xbanghead

 
 You should read into more about music and art. You'll find they're connected to math and science in many ways. For a first example, look at the Fibonacci series and the structure of chords in music. (1)-1-2-3-5-8 (yes that's an octave)-13... this is but one example.

You should read into more about music and art. You'll find they're connected to math and science in many ways. For a first example, look at the Fibonacci series and the structure of chords in music. (1)-1-2-3-5-8 (yes that's an octave)-13... this is but one example.

 
 So why teach it indirectly, then? emoticon_confused

So why teach it indirectly, then? emoticon_confused

 
 It's all about the presentation, and realistic applicability. 
 
 
Music is a kind of art class and is therefore one of the most important parts of a school. Art classes are the most important and foundational classes, and should be at the center of all schools - with all other lessions relateing to them.

 
 I don't know if art classes should be the focal point, but I do think that lessons should relate across the board. Say, you're reading Chaucer in English class. Let's talk about that in the literary sense, in the history sense, the musical sense (he mentioned specific musical instruments), the visual art sense (who was doing what then), the science sense (had the apple fallen from the tree yet?) etc. I think students get a better idea of the big picture this way.

Surely someone has brought up the point that people involved with music in school do significantly better. I was at a "Miss Teen of Virginia" scholarship program the other day (not a beauty pageant for those wondering) and the wise kids all played some kind of instrument and most studied latin.

Surely someone has brought up the point that people involved with music in school do significantly better. I was at a "Miss Teen of Virginia" scholarship program the other day (not a beauty pageant for those wondering) and the wise kids all played some kind of instrument and most studied latin.

 
 I've found the same holds true, but if you have limited class time, I vote for academics. You can take music lessons on your own, privately.

I've found the same holds true, but if you have limited class time, I vote for academics. You can take music lessons on your own, privately.

 
 How do you define acedemics? Isn't English, besides basic reading/writing a form of art? Should we cut that out after elementary school since they all can communicate fine?

I've found the same holds true, but if you have limited class time, I vote for academics. You can take music lessons on your own, privately.

 
 You can, but you shouldn't have limited class time. I suppose we could produce a bunch of single minded folks who won't grasp the concept of what they are learning but if we want to have a valuable education system, music and other classes are key. Application of concepts is one of the best learning tools...music does this as well as some arts and things of that nature. Even PE and field trips provide more learning experience than one would realize.

How do you define acedemics? Isn't English, besides basic reading/writing a form of art? Should we cut that out after elementary school since they all can communicate fine?

 
 Ever hear of the 3 R's. :) No, seriously, learning to communicate in writing is very important as well as math and science. While I see value in music and art, when your education system is almost dead last in the world, it's time to get back to the basics.
 Not surprisingly, American students rank amongst the highest in self-esteem. Unfortunately, thinking your great doesn't build bridges, cars, cure the sick, etc.

You can, but you shouldn't have limited class time. I suppose we could produce a bunch of single minded folks who won't grasp the concept of what they are learning but if we want to have a valuable education system, music and other classes are key. Application of concepts is one of the best learning tools...music does this as well as some arts and things of that nature. Even PE and field trips provide more learning experience than one would realize.

 
 I loved field trips. They were great times to screw off. emoticon_xgood

I'm all for music in school. If they had to get rid of music and other art departments, I would suggest that the teachers at least study some music themselves to be more interesting. I remember the funnest teachers (even now in college) were the ones who were open to the students involvement with music (part of or listening to.) My Freshman year of high school, I took World Geography and the teacher had some CD's and let us listen to music of the different contanents. Even Antartica...
 
 By the way, Antartica doesn't have it's own style of music, but if I could place it as something, imagine combining Celtic with 80's love ballads with a little bit to the soundtrack to the movie version of Lost In Space. Maybe throw in some of Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure when they are in the future. Those 4 combined isn't truely what it sounded like but it's how I would describe it.
 
 Over all, my view on music and other forms of art in school is this. If it weren't for the arts, I would not have been able to make it through school at all.

My Freshman year of high school, I took World Geography and the teacher had some CD's and let us listen to music of the different contanents. Even Antartica...

 
 This is what I'm talking about. Integration. 
 
 (I think Antartica sounds like minimalism. emoticon_xgood )
 
 
You can take music lessons on your own, privately.

 Sure you can, but music is a "group sport". Playing an instrument without an ensemble loses some of the benefits. 
 
 
Surely someone has brought up the point that people involved with music in school do significantly better
.
 
 I'm not sure anyone has, so here are some examples from the Nat'l Association of Music Education.MENC 
 
 
 Secondary students who participated in band or orchestra reported the lowest lifetime and current use of all substances (alcohol, tobacco, illicit drugs). - Texas Commission on Drug and Alcohol Abuse Report. Reported in Houston Chronicle, January 1998 
 
 A study of 237 second grade children used piano keyboard training and newly designed math software to demonstrate improvement in math skills. The group scored 27% higher on proportional math and fractions tests than children that used only the math software. - Graziano, Amy, Matthew Peterson, and Gordon Shaw, "Enhanced learning of proportional math through music training and spatial-temporal training." Neurological Research 21 (March 1999). 
 
 Students with coursework/experience in music performance and music appreciation scored higher on the SAT: students in music performance scored 57 points higher on the verbal and 41 points higher on the math, and students in music appreciation scored 63 points higher on verbal and 44 points higher on the math, than did students with no arts participation. - College-Bound Seniors National Report: Profile of SAT Program Test Takers. Princeton, NJ: The College Entrance Examination Board, 2001. 
 
 Most of the negative stuff I've found, from other sources, specify the negative effects of rap music in school age children. But that's a completely different topic.

Ever hear of the 3 R's. :) No, seriously, learning to communicate in writing is very important as well as math and science. While I see value in music and art, when your education system is almost dead last in the world, it's time to get back to the basics.
 Not surprisingly, American students rank amongst the highest in self-esteem. Unfortunately, thinking your great doesn't build bridges, cars, cure the sick, etc.

 
 Well I can communicate pretty well. Sure I've gotten better the last few years and will continue to get better at writing with English classes and will hopefully learn something from books I read, but do you honestly think I wold have trouble expressing myself if I just stopped taking English classes now? (Senior year in high school and college)

Sure I've gotten better the last few years and will continue to get better at writing with English classes and will hopefully learn something from books I read, but do you honestly think I wold have trouble expressing myself if I just stopped taking English classes now? (Senior year in high school and college)

 
 Depending on your high school, I believe that English doesn't need to be taught in college. The one exception that I've found was if you intend to become a technical writer. There are certain rules that technical writers follow that aren't the same as those taught in HS. 
 Freshman English Composition is a joke if you already know how to write term papers, but is needed if you don't.
 
 And....verbal communication today is at least as important as the written word. I've had a dozen chemists work for me over the last 20 years. The most successful ones were those that were also comfortable at public speaking. It opened up opportunities outside of the lab that wouldn't be available for someone not comfortable with talking to groups.

Depending on your high school, I believe that English doesn't need to be taught in college. The one exception that I've found was if you intend to become a technical writer. There are certain rules that technical writers follow that aren't the same as those taught in HS. 
 Freshman English Composition is a joke if you already know how to write term papers, but is needed if you don't.

 I'm a Creative Writing English major, does that count?

Depending on your high school, I believe that English doesn't need to be taught in college. 
 I think it needs to be taught more in college. Maybe not "English" as you know it but more along the lines of business writting.

I'm a Creative Writing English major, does that count?

 
 WTF is that? Can you actually get a job in the real world with such a degree? emoticon_confused

WTF is that? Can you actually get a job in the real world with such a degree? emoticon_confused

 Read any good novels lately?

Read any good novels lately?

 
 Not one that was written by a author with a Creative Writing degree. :)
 I'm a believer that creativity is inate, not learned.

Okay, I was a bit hasty with that statement. I am sorry.
 I should have included that you can also write song lyrics. You can also write scripts for plays or film. You can also write poetry. I've actually gotten some poetry of mine published before...twice. The first was in the news paper when I was in 6th grade for a poem I wrote on MLK Jr. Then in college, I had a poem published in the colleges literary magazine. The poem was called "For Legal Carnival Knowledge."

Not one that was written by a author with a Creative Writing degree. :)
 I'm a believer that creativity is inate, not learned.

 So why not get paid for what comes naturally?

So why not get paid for what comes naturally?

 
 I do....and my college degree is in Chemistry. I've had several of my technical papers published in various forms over the years. I just never believed that one had to major in writing to do so. emoticon_wow
